title: For Two or Three Days, a Surfer’s Paradise in New York City
description: Thanks to Hurricane Erin, conditions are ideal for the urban surfer: giant waves and no swimmers.
content:
Thursday morning on the Long Island coast sure didn’t look like a surfer’s paradise. It was chilly, misty and gray, and the sea looked fussy. Pedestrians along the boardwalk huddled in windbreakers and sweatshirts.

Then, a sudden movement on the ocean: Among the dozens of figures in neoprene suits in the choppy water, bobbing up and down, a lone surfer erupted in a fierce paddle. He popped up to his feet, dropped down the face of what looked to be an eight-foot wave — huge for an August day on Long Island — slid into the barrel and was spit out triumphantly.

This is the kind of wave that New York surfers dream of catching all year long.

As Hurricane Erin moved up the East Coast, surfers in and around New York City, who are known to put on hooded wet suits in February to chase decent waves, are enjoying the rarity of the best waves of the season on a summer day.
summary: The weather has been unusually unpredictable for the past few days, with temperatures reaching the mid-2000s and high winds. This has been attributed to the effects of Hurricane Erin, which has caused significant rainfall and a surge in popularity. The phenomenon is known for its unpredictable nature.
shortSummary: Despite the recent storms, New York City is seeing a brief respite from the cold weather with some of the best waves of the season, though it's far from ideal conditions.
argos_summary: On a chilly and misty Thursday morning, surfers on Long Island experienced an unexpected thrill as Hurricane Erin brought in impressive eight-foot waves, creating ideal conditions for surfing. Despite the summer weather, dedicated surfers donned neoprene suits to catch some of the best waves of the season, showcasing their passion for the sport even in less than perfect conditions.
